issues.description: The solution repository uses classes named SpaceGoat, SpacePig, and SpaceSeal instead of the animal class names (Goat, Pig, Seal) shown in the problem UML and used in the example Main. The solution also contains (apparently empty) Goat.java, Pig.java, and Seal.java files, while the concrete implementations live in the Space* classes. This mismatch between the problem specification (and the example usage) and the solution class names will confuse students: the problem and UML refer to Goat/Pig/Seal, the template/main expect those names, but the reference implementation provides SpaceGoat/SpacePig/SpaceSeal. It also changes the runtime class names (and thus printed animal type in the song and milk/ride messages) compared to what students will expect from the specification.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution repository use the same concrete class names as the problem specification and template (Goat, Pig, Seal). Either rename SpaceGoat/SpacePig/SpaceSeal to Goat/Pig/Seal (and update their constructors/returned strings accordingly), or provide proper Goat, Pig, and Seal implementations (possibly delegating to or extending the Space* classes). Ensure the example Main and any printed messages reflect the same animal class names as the UML/specification.

issues.description: The template's Farm.singFarmSongVerse method currently has its Animal parameter commented out (private void singFarmSongVerse(/*Animal animal*/)), while the UML in the problem statement and the solution implementation expect a parameter singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal). The commented-out parameter in the template could confuse students about the intended signature and whether the helper should accept an Animal.
issues.suggested_fix: Uncomment or add the Animal parameter in the template method signature so it matches the UML and the solution: private void singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal). This clarifies the intended helper method signature and removes ambiguity for students implementing the song logic.

issues.description: The problem statement and template refer to concrete animal classes named Seal, Pig, and Goat (UML and Main.java instantiations), but the solution repository implements these concrete animals with different names: SpaceSeal, SpacePig, and SpaceGoat. This is a direct naming mismatch for the same conceptual entities (concrete animal classes). Students reading the problem and template will look for Seal.java / Pig.java / Goat.java implementations; the solution's implementations live under different identifiers, which breaks the straightforward mapping from requirements to implementation and may cause confusion when comparing expected class names, constructing instances in Main, or checking return strings that embed the class name.
issues.suggested_fix: Align concrete animal class names across artifacts. Either (A) rename the solution classes to the problem/template expected names (SpaceSeal -> Seal, SpacePig -> Pig, SpaceGoat -> Goat) and update any in-class strings accordingly, or (B) add wrapper classes with the expected names that delegate to the existing Space* implementations (e.g., public class Seal extends SpaceSeal { public Seal(String name) { super(name); } }). This preserves the conceptual mapping so students can find and instantiate Seal/Pig/Goat as described in the exercise.
